file_name: AudibleInc_20001113_10-Q_EX-10.32_2599586_EX-10.32_Co-Branding Agreement_ Marketing Agreement_ Investment Distribution Agreement.pdf

perturbation.original_text:
Payments called for by this Section 5 which are not
received within five (5) business days after the date upon which payment is due
will bear interest at a rate equal to the lesser of one and one-half percent (1-
1/2%) per month or the maximum legal rate permitted under the controlling Laws.
perturbation.changed_text: Payments called for by this Section 5 which are not received within thirty (30) business days after the date upon which payment is due will not bear any interest, irrespective of state or federal usury laws.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts standard business practices and potentially violates state usury laws, which often mandate interest on late payments and set maximum allowable interest rates. Removing any interest for late payments and setting the payment due date to an extreme of thirty days introduces non-compliance.

perturbation.original_text:
Each Party will, during the Term and for a period of one (1) year thereafter, maintain complete and accurate books and records
sufficient to verify its compliance or non-compliance with the provisions of
this Section 9 (and, in the case of Company, Section 5.4  [Royalties]). Each Party (the
"Audited Party") will, upon at least thirty (30) days' prior written request by
the other Party (the "Auditing Party"), allow an independent certified public
accounting firm selected by the Auditing Party and reasonably acceptable to the
Audited Party to audit such books and records at the Audited Party's premises to
the extent necessary to verify the Audited Party's compliance or non-compliance
with the provisions of this Section 9 (or, in the case of Company, Section 5.4  [Royalties]);
perturbation.changed_text: Neither Party is required to maintain any books and records pertaining to this agreement. Audits are disallowed under any circumstances.
perturbation.explanation: This change conflicts with generally accepted accounting principles and legal requirements for businesses to maintain records for tax and regulatory compliance. Preventing any audits introduces non-compliance with standard business practices and potential violations of regulations requiring financial transparency.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Sarbanes-Oxley Act, SEC regulations, state corporate laws.

perturbation.original_text:
Without limiting the foregoing, the
Receiving Party will: (a) use such Confidential Information solely for the
purposes for which it has been disclosed; and (b) disclose such Confidential
Information only to those of its and its Affiliates' employees, agents, and
consultants who have a need to know the same for the purpose of performing this
Agreement and who are informed of and agree to a duty of nondisclosure.
perturbation.changed_text: The Receiving Party may disclose Confidential Information to any third party without prior consent and without any obligation to maintain confidentiality.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly negates the purpose of a confidentiality clause and violates standard practices for protecting proprietary information. It allows for unrestricted disclosure, which conflicts with trade secret laws and common law protections for confidential information. This creates legal risks related to intellectual property and competitive advantage.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secrets Act, Common Law principles of confidentiality.
